newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian General News - Feb 3.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian General News - Feb 3.

text.p: THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

Industrial Relations Minister Peter Reith has left open the possibility of a second round of industrial relations reforms if the reforms introduced last year do not significantly reduce unemployment. The original reform package was watered down in negotiaions with the Australian Democrats in order to get the legislation through the Senate. Page 1.

An agreement between the New South Wales Government and the Dunghutti people of Crescent Head in New South Wales has valued native title at up to 150 per cent of the freehold value of the land. The starting point for negotiation put a value on native title rights of at least the full freehold value of the land - a more valuable and secure form of tenure than leasehold. Page 1.

Australian Olympic Committee director and Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games and International Olympic Games delegate Phil Coles has hit back at criticism over his accepting a board position with Balsam Pacific - a company expected to win large contracts from the construction of sporting facilities at Sydney's Homebush Bay games site. Page 2.

The release of new data this week is expected to show the level of activity in the housing and retail sectors and test the Federal Government's new economic forecasts. Analysts remain pessimistic about the state of the economy, especially after the release of the National Australia Bank Ltd's growth forecast of only 2.75 percent for 1996-97. Page 3.
THE AUSTRALIAN

Prime Minister John Howard is expected to announce a People's Convention on the republic later this year. The Federal Cabinet has endorsed the plan, subject to the approval of Government MPs, in which half the delegates will be elected according to criteria to ensure representation from young, indigenous Australians, interest groups, State and Federal Governments and Opposition parties. Page 1.

The Australian Taxation Office is facing major problems in the development of measures to prevent tax cheating on the Internet, and may be unable to close the holes in the tax net by the end of the decade. The dilemma was cited by the Government as one of the general risks to the nation's crumbling revenue base. Page 1.

The latest figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicate almost three-quarters of teaching staff in Australia's primary schools are female - many aged 40 or over. Another recently released study from the Australian Council of Deans of Education raised the issue of teacher ages, with one-third of Australian teachers found to be aged between 40 and 55. Page 1. --

Federal Schools Minister David Kemp said yesterday school students as young as five will be introduced to the workings of Australia's systems of Government with the long-awaited civics curriculum. He said Australia's world-leading system of democratic voting was something which should be passed on to students. Page 2.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

A proposal to be put to the Coalition party room tomorrow would see a People's Convention, comprising both appointed and elected delegates, held at the end of the year to frame a referendum on the republic at a cost of A$55 million. Serving politicians will be barred from running in an effort to prevent the ballot becoming a party-numbers crunching exercise. Page 1.

Cuts to the NSW Legal Aid Commission will see more people spend the weekend in detention as the commission cannot afford to pay its workers to work on Saturdays and Sundays. Currently, anyone arrested and detained on a weekend is entitled to free legal reresentation at weekend bail courts. Page 1.

Acting Commonwealth Privacy Commissioner Nigel Waters has called for changes in privacy laws after claiming health funds are looking at patients' records without their permission. Waters said the private sector should be brought into line with the public sector in terms of privacy issues. Page 2.

A coalition of leading transport and environment groups says the Roads and Traffic Authority is misrepresenting traffic estimates to justify pushing ahead with the controversial Eastern Distributor tollway. The claims came yesterday at a rally to protest gainst the A$600 million road project. Page 2.
THE AGE

The Victorian Government is in danger of losing its second-safest rural seat after a 13 percent swing to Labor in yesterday's Gippsland West elections, forced by the departure of former Transport Minister Alan Brown. At the close of counting, Labor-aligned Independent Susan Davies had 50.63 per cent of the two-party preferred vote, compared with 49.37 per cent for Liberal candidate Matthew Coleman. Page 1.

A move by the British Government to impose mandatory life terms on offenders who commit a second violent crime will be examined by Victorian director of public prosecutions Richard Read when he travels to England this month to examine the British stance on crime and punishment. Page 1.

A push by the Transport Workers Union for an 11 percent rise has sparked fears by employers of a wage break-out and undermined the Workplace Relations Act. The 90,000-strong TWU has asked the Industrial Relations Commission for the rise to workers covere by the Federal transport award. Page A3.

As Prime Minister John Howard returns to Canberra, he faces battles over social and economic issues such as euthanasia, the Wik native title case and a possible Australian republic as his Government approaches the end of its first year in office with the first parliamentary sittings of 1997. Page A3.
(Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
